title: Case Study: Lupus-Induced Musculoskeletal Pain in a Young Adult
clinical_history: A 28-year-old female, Sarah, presents with a 6-month history of recurring joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the mornings. She reports difficulty walking and performing daily activities due to pain and fatigue. Sarah was diagnosed with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE or Lupus) 2 years ago, and her symptoms have been managed with medication. However, she has recently experienced increased disease activity, manifesting as joint inflammation and musculoskeletal pain.
aggrevating_factors: Prolonged standing, walking, or climbing stairs; morning stiffness lasting several hours
picture: A 24-hour pain profile showing increased pain in the morning and evening
easing_factors: Rest, ice packs, and pain medication
past_history: History of recurrent pleurisy and pericarditis; hospitalizations for disease flares
medical_history: Diagnosed with Lupus 2 years ago; hypertension; hyperlipidemia
personal_history: Recently divorced; working part-time as a freelance writer; experiencing stress and anxiety
imaging: X-rays showing joint erosions and osteoporosis; MRI indicating synovitis and tendonitis
